awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  High-speed, precision wire plotting for electromechanical sensors and actuators
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impacts of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project enables a cost-effective expansion of generation and storage of renewable electricity.  Electricity demand is expected to grow by 80% or more by 2050, and smart grid technologies have a compound annual growth rate of 20% with a market estimated at $35 B. One important element of the grid is the transformer, a critical enabler of large scale vehicle-to-grid technology necessary for greater electric vehicle adoption. This project advances a new transformer manufacturing technology that will lower hardware costs of grid infrastructure and decrease construction and permitting costs, which can account for as much as 85% of total costs.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project uses precision additive manufacturing to enable solid state transformers for the next-generation electric grid. By operating at higher frequencies, solid state transformers provide power conversion and grid services with high power density and lower hardware and project costs. Currently, solid state transformers are hampered by their wirewound electromagnetic components that perform poorly at high frequencies and are costly to produce. This project will enable new classes of devices with 10x improvements in performance. This project will produce technology demonstration prototypes of a power conversion product and plan for translation at scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Foli Research developed an additive manufacturing process for plotting precision electromagnetics at low cost. The goal of the Phase II SBIR project was to mature and further de-risk this technology for successful market adoption. This program was driven by one key question: Can the quality that we have achieved at low volume be maintained while scaling production throughput? To answer this, we outlined three technical objectives: Build a high throughput manufacturing cell; Add the production capabilities required by the wireless power industry; and Implement a digital workflow to streamline new customer adoption and technology transfer. 

To achieve the goals set forth, we expanded our lab prototype platform to use industrially-sized stock and to operate as one continuous process. After validating the concepts on the prototype machine, we designed and built the pilot manufacturing cell with several capability updates (e.g. quick tool changes and larger variety of wire type and sizes). Instead of developing novel techniques we relied on proven manufacturing processes, as seen in the web conversion industry, to create a robust and reliable manufacturing platform. We then validated our new industrial machine and proved that we could maintain part quality while increasing throughput.

Last, we developed software and a graphical user interface so that our machine could easily be used by others. To do so, we created an interface that incorporates common computer-aided design and manufacturing workflows, including: the importing and exporting of widely used design formats; an integrated design generation tool; design rule checking for manufacturability; and a machine control system with collision detection and 3d path planning.

These objectives would be futile without market engagement so we grew our understanding of our value proposition through prototype programs with industry partners. Additionally, we contracted a business consultant to refine and roll out our customer engagement process, and we hired an industry partner to perform a technical product discovery to further document our value proposition in today’s markets.


 


Last Modified: 03/19/2024
Modified by: Tucker R Gilman
